finding: The SNP rs9404989 associated with hypothyroidism in the HCG26 locus had a significantly higher odds ratio of 1.90 in the top quartile of functional genomic network disease (FGND) topic weight versus 1.19 in the bottom quartile, with significance at P=3×10^-3 for the difference.
title: Age-dependent topic modelling of comorbidities in UK Biobank identifies disease subtypes with differential genetic risk

finding: The SNP rs2187668 was part of the T1DGRS generated using published variants associated with the risk of Type 1 Diabetes (T1D). It contributed to identifying the HLA DR haplotype in individuals from the UK Biobank, which was critical for ascertaining the HLA-haplotype component of genetic risk scores.
title: Estimating population level disease prevalence using genetic risk scores

finding: The SNP rs7454108 was also included in the T1DGRS related to Type 1 Diabetes risk. Similar to rs2187668, it played a role in determining the HLA DR haplotype and was essential in calculating the genetic risk scores pertaining to T1D in the UK Biobank.
title: Estimating population level disease prevalence using genetic risk scores

finding: This SNP was associated with timing of L5 and other sleep-related behaviors, contributing to previously known sleep and activity associations.
title: Genome-wide association studies of 27 accelerometry-derived physical activity measurements identifies novel loci and genetic mechanisms

finding: The SNP rs62401887 at position 24416482 on chromosome 6 was strongly associated with the hepatic biological age gap (BAG) and mapped to the MRS2 gene, which has a deleterious score of 14.89 and an eQTL P-value of 1.09×10^-10, indicative of its role in magnesium ion transmembrane transporter activity.
title: The Genetic Architecture of Biological Age in Nine Human Organ Systems

finding: The SNP rs80215559 at position 25918225 on chromosome 6 was linked to the immune BAG, suggesting specific genetic contributions to variations in immune-related aging processes.
title: The Genetic Architecture of Biological Age in Nine Human Organ Systems

finding: The SNP rs79220007 at position 26098474 on chromosome 6 was associated with the metabolic BAG, offering insights into genetic factors influencing metabolic aging.
title: The Genetic Architecture of Biological Age in Nine Human Organ Systems

finding: The SNP rs2744575 at position 24494975 on chromosome 6 was related to the musculoskeletal BAG, indicating a genetic basis for aging-related changes in musculoskeletal health.
title: The Genetic Architecture of Biological Age in Nine Human Organ Systems

finding: The SNP rs411535 at position 22061040 on chromosome 6 was associated with the pulmonary BAG, highlighting its role in aging-related pulmonary health phenomena.
title: The Genetic Architecture of Biological Age in Nine Human Organ Systems

finding: The SNP rs55925606 at position 25878848 on chromosome 6 was connected to the renal BAG, reflecting genetic influences on kidney aging.
title: The Genetic Architecture of Biological Age in Nine Human Organ Systems

finding: The SNP rs143334143, near the CCHCR1 gene, was associated with asthma, recording an OR of 0.94 (p=2.31 x 10^-4), indicating a possible protective role against severe COVID-19 through associations with respiratory diseases.
title: A Phenome-Wide Association Study of genes associated with COVID-19 severity reveals shared genetics with complex diseases in the Million Veteran Program

finding: The p.C282Y variant (rs1800562) of the HFE gene was associated with a cumulative incidence of haemochromatosis diagnoses in males, with a baseline prevalence of 12.1% and a cumulative incidence of 56.4% by age 80. This genotype also correlated with higher mortality rates (HR 1.29) and increased risks for multiple outcomes, including joint replacements and liver disease.
title: HFE genotypes, haemochromatosis diagnosis and clinical outcomes to age 80: a prospective cohort study in UK Biobank

finding: The p.H63D variant (rs1799945) did not exhibit significant excess morbidity when compared with the p.C282Y variant. In both males and females carrying the p.C282Y/p.H63D genotype, there were no statistically significant excess outcomes for fatigue or depression, indicating that while it was part of the genotype analysis, it did not present independent negative health outcomes in this study.
title: HFE genotypes, haemochromatosis diagnosis and clinical outcomes to age 80: a prospective cohort study in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs9273368 was associated with type 1 diabetes (phecode 250.1) with a highly significant p-value of 4.23e-106, corroborating previous findings related to diabetes medication use in the GWAS Catalog.
title: The Michigan Genomics Initiative: a biobank linking genotypes and electronic clinical records in Michigan Medicine patients

finding: SNP rs9505286 was identified as a genome-wide significant locus associated with urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio (UACR) in the MetaSSA analysis on chromosome 6 (p=4.3×10^-8). It was located in the intronic regions of BMP6 and was associated with the expression of BMP6 and RREB1, suggesting links to kidney disease.
title: Genetic Association and Transferability for Urinary Albumin-Creatinine Ratio as a Marker of Kidney Disease in four Sub-Saharan African Populations and non-continental Individuals of African Ancestry

finding: This SNP was identified as a male-specific genome-wide significant signal associated with CRF-vo2max. It was found to be an intron variant in the gene TRMT11, and functional analyses suggested a shared SNP driving the association with expression of HINT3 in skeletal muscle.
title: The genetic case for cardiorespiratory fitness as a clinical vital sign and the routine prescription of physical activity in healthcare

finding: This male-specific SNP was significant for physical activity (PA) and was identified as an intron variant of IMPG1. It showed significant heterogeneity in the analysis.
title: The genetic case for cardiorespiratory fitness as a clinical vital sign and the routine prescription of physical activity in healthcare

finding: The study reported that the SNP rs9277534 was significantly associated with DPB1 expression levels, being used to categorize patients into high (G allele) and low (A allele) expression mismatches when mismatched with donor DPB1 alleles. This categorization was crucial in analyzing the impact of DPB1 mismatches on acute graft versus host disease (aGVHD) outcomes, where significant hazards were observed for individuals with two mismatches compared to perfect matching.
title: Machine Learning Insights into HLA Noncoding Sequence Mismatches and Their Impact on DPB1 Matching in Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation

finding: The SNP rs10455872, located in the LPA gene, exhibited a dominance effect on lipoprotein(a) levels. This variant was associated with coronary disease, as established in the literature, indicating its significant role in influencing lipid biomarkers.
title: Improved prediction of blood biomarkers using deep learning

finding: SNP rs2571381, located on chromosome 6, was found to be significantly associated with reactions to the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine. This SNP showed a strong association (p=1.16E-12) in participants reporting severe difficulties with daily routines after vaccination.
title: HLA-A*03:01 is associated with increased risk of fever, chills, and more severe reaction to Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccination

finding: This variant was noted as significant in the GWAS, associated with severe difficulties with daily routine post-vaccination, and was identified as the lead SNP demonstrating a strong correlation with the HLA-G gene region.
title: HLA-A*03:01 is associated with increased risk of fever, chills, and more severe reaction to Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccination

finding: Leading SNP chr6:29945053:T:C was significantly associated with vaccine reactions in the context of the Pfizer vaccine, exhibiting a notable association with severe difficulties reported (p=1.16E-12).
title: HLA-A*03:01 is associated with increased risk of fever, chills, and more severe reaction to Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccination

finding: The SNP rs10305420, located near GLP1R, was part of the Hyper Insulin cluster and associated with the target of GLP1 receptor agonists, which are known to potentiate insulin secretion.
title: Multi-ancestry Polygenic Mechanisms of Type 2 Diabetes Elucidate Disease Processes and Clinical Heterogeneity

finding: The SNP rs998584 located near VEGF was included in the Lipodystrophy 1 cluster, linked to treatments for diabetic retinopathy through VEGF inhibitors.
title: Multi-ancestry Polygenic Mechanisms of Type 2 Diabetes Elucidate Disease Processes and Clinical Heterogeneity

finding: The SNP rs9467663 was associated with high-gain weight cluster membership, with an odds ratio of 1.011, indicating its role in obesity trajectories.
title: The genetic architecture of changes in adiposity during adulthood

finding: The SNP rs72560793 was one of the four loci jointly associated with head BMD and IA, suggesting shared genetic factors affecting both conditions.
title: GWAS of ∼30,000 samples with bone mineral density at multiple skeletal sites and its clinical relevance on fracture prediction, genetic correlations and prioritization of drug targets

finding: The rs36215567 variant (NM_182961.4: c.20396+22A>G) in the SYNE1 gene was significantly associated with myocardial infarction (MI) in young patients with a family history of premature atherosclerosis. This variant occurred more frequently in the studied group, exhibiting an odds ratio of 4.80 (95% CI 1.43-14.45, p=0.005) when compared to the control population, and an odds ratio of 9.31 (95% CI 1.64-95.41, p=0.004) when compared to a matched control group by age and gender. Furthermore, in a multivariable logistic regression model that accounted for smoking status and BMI, this SNP was confirmed as an independent risk factor for premature MI, with an odds ratio of 13.86 (95% CI 1.64-117.45, p=0.016). This finding indicated the potential role of the SYNE1 gene variant in genetic risk scores for MI.
title: SYNE1 gene novel variant is associated with myocardial infarction in young people with a family history of premature atherosclerosis

finding: This SNP was implicated in PSA variation and was linked to the HLA region, concluding that it holds potential importance in prostate cancer risk assessments.
title: Leveraging Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Towards Improving Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: Located in <italic>JARID2</italic>, this SNP was identified as significant in relation to PSA, suggesting its role in cancer risk assessment.
title: Leveraging Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Towards Improving Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: The rs12333117 SNP showed significant contributions to the model correlating with NRN1 gene expression in the PFC of SZ-Clz individuals, with a standardized β of -0.364 (p=0.045). This variant influenced gene expression and had implications related to schizophrenia. Additionally, its presence was noted to affect enhancer and promoter function, indicating its regulatory role.
title: CLOZAPINE-RELATED BRAIN NRN1 EXPRESSION PATTERNS ARE ASSOCIATED WITH METHYLATION AND GENETIC VARIANTS IN SCHIZOPHRENIA

finding: The rs2208870 SNP was found to significantly enhance the correlation with NRN1 gene expression in the PFC, with a standardized β of -0.404 (p=0.029) when combined with LC1 scores. This SNP also contributed to understanding the regulatory dynamics of NRN1 expression and was indicated to alter transcription factor binding affinities.
title: CLOZAPINE-RELATED BRAIN NRN1 EXPRESSION PATTERNS ARE ASSOCIATED WITH METHYLATION AND GENETIC VARIANTS IN SCHIZOPHRENIA

finding: SNP rs998584 was linked to multiple cardiometabolic phenotypes, showing that the allele associated with increased BFP corresponded to an increase in gluteofemoral adipose tissue (GFAT), a decrease in visceral adipose tissue (VAT), and a reduced risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D) and CAD.
title: Sex-stratified GWAS of Body Fat Percentage after Adjusting for Testosterone and SHBG in the UK Biobank

finding: The study found that the TT genotype of rs1360780 significantly interacted with child abuse to predict resting-state functional connectivity (rsFC) between the right centromedial amygdala and right posterior insula. Specifically, TT allele carriers with a history of abuse showed stronger rsFC compared to those without history of abuse, suggesting a heightened vulnerability to alterations in brain communication that process emotions and sensations. This supports findings indicating that rs1360780 may contribute to increased risk of stress-related psychopathology, particularly in individuals with early-life stress.
title: The Interaction of Child Abuse and rs1360780 of the FKBP5 Gene is Associated with Amygdala Resting-State Functional Connectivity in Young Adults

finding: The SNP rs137852949, identified in the Finnish population, had a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.00748, indicating it bordered on the classification of a 'rare' variant. It was implicated as a heterozygous cause of polycystic liver disease and its enrichment in the cohort suggested its role as a monoallelic contributor to cystic kidney disease.
title: Quantifying variant contributions in cystic kidney disease using national-scale whole genome sequencing

finding: The minor C-allele at rs2504706 was associated with a higher intake of cereal and a lower intake of coffee. The association was significant, with a beta of 0.058 (95% CIs=[0.042, 0.073], P=2.94E-13) for cereal, and a beta of -0.034 (95% CIs=[-0.045, -0.023], P=1.67E-09) for coffee. This finding contributed to understanding the genetic factors affecting dietary preferences.
title: Increased brain volume from higher cereal and lower coffee intake: Shared genetic determinants and impacts on cognition and metabolism

finding: The SNP rs9281226 was associated with the HLA region, with a strong correlation to the HLA allele HLA-B*08:01, showing an r² of 0.67, although it was not the best match for any known HLA-allele.
title: Comprehensive genome-wide association study of different forms of hernia identifies more than 80 associated loci

finding: the significant signal for opioid use disorder (OUD) mapped to OPRM1, a critical gene in opioid response.
title: Multivariate genome-wide association meta-analysis of over 1 million subjects identifies loci underlying multiple substance use disorders

finding: This SNP was related to cervical dysplasia with a significant p-value (p=9.1 × 10⁻⁹), mapping to the HLA-B gene, which is crucial in immune response.
title: GWAS meta-analysis and gene expression data link reproductive tract development, immune response and cellular proliferation/apoptosis with cervical cancer and clarify overlap with other cervical phenotypes

finding: Associated with cervical dysplasia (p=1.6 × 10⁻²²), this SNP also maps to the HLA-DQA1 gene, further supporting its involvement in cervical pathology.
title: GWAS meta-analysis and gene expression data link reproductive tract development, immune response and cellular proliferation/apoptosis with cervical cancer and clarify overlap with other cervical phenotypes

finding: This SNP is associated with cervical cancer (p=1.0 × 10⁻³⁹) and is located in the HLA region, emphasizing its connection to immune responses related to cervical pathology.
title: GWAS meta-analysis and gene expression data link reproductive tract development, immune response and cellular proliferation/apoptosis with cervical cancer and clarify overlap with other cervical phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs9461856 was found to overlap with infrequent but statistically significant variants in SYNGAP1, which had been associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in over 50 studies, and was identified as an NMI-SV in 17% of ASD cases.
title: Structural Variants Are a Major Component of the Missing Heritability of Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: The SNP rs2051449 marked an ASD-SV in GRIK2, linked to glutamate signaling with a significant impact, showing reduced transcripts in ASD cases indicating disrupted neuronal pathways.
title: Structural Variants Are a Major Component of the Missing Heritability of Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: In the same meta-analytic GWAS for MDD, this SNP was found to have a beta of -0.011 and a p-value of 3.3 × 10^-8. It was also recognized as a significant genetic contributor related to MDD liability.
title: PA-FGRS is a novel estimator of pedigree-based genetic liability that complements genotype-based inferences into the genetic architecture of major depressive disorder

finding: This SNP was also significant in the case-control GWAS for MDD with a beta of -0.073 and a p-value of 4.6 × 10^-8, reinforcing its role in genetic risk associated with MDD.
title: PA-FGRS is a novel estimator of pedigree-based genetic liability that complements genotype-based inferences into the genetic architecture of major depressive disorder

finding: The SNP rs1799971 at the OPRM1 locus was reported in the original OUD GWAS, highlighting its association with opioid use disorder.
title: Genome-wide analyses reveal novel opioid use disorder loci and genetic overlap with schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and major depression

finding: In the largest genome-wide association study (GWAS) of opioid use disorder (OUD) involving 15,756 cases and 99,039 controls, rs1799971, a variant in the gene encoding the mu opioid receptor (OPRM1), was identified as genome-wide significant. However, its effect size was small (β = -0.066 [SE = 0.012]), and despite being statistically significant, it was deemed unlikely to be clinically relevant.
title: Genetic Data Can Lead to Medical Discrimination: Opioid Use Disorder as a Cautionary Tale

finding: The rs9381564 variant near the CD2AP gene was part of the Longevity-group and reached significance in both the current study and the parental-longevity GWAS.
title: The effect of Alzheimer’s disease-associated genetic variants on longevity

finding: The rs9275152 variant in the HLA region was noted to be associated with longevity despite showing counterintuitive effects regarding AD risk, as reported in different studies.
title: The effect of Alzheimer’s disease-associated genetic variants on longevity

finding: Identified a strong association with the immediate recall memory phenotype achieving a P value of 7.50E-11, indicating its significance for cognitive function.
title: Genome-wide association study of Alzheimer’s disease brain imaging biomarkers and neuropsychological phenotypes in the EMIF-AD Multimodal Biomarker Discovery dataset

finding: The study found that carriers or homozygotes of the minor allele T (CT + TT) for the HMGA1 SNP rs41269028 had a height of 162.88 cm ± 6.001, while those homozygous for the major allele (CC) had a height of 162.29 cm ± 6.18. This difference in height was statistically significant (p = 0.005). Additionally, a greater proportion of tall women with breast cancer (11.9%) were carriers or homozygotes of the minor allele T compared to short women (6.8%, p = 0.02, two-tail Fisher exact test). However, the genotype did not significantly relate to breast cancer risk (p = 0.602) or survival (p = 0.439). Thus, HMGA1 was concluded to influence height but not the incidence or prognosis of breast cancer in tall women.
title: Tall women with breast cancer have poorer survival than short women

finding: The rs4151667 SNP, associated with the BF gene in the C2/BF haplotype, was correlated with the presence of soft drusen, which indicated a risk factor for advanced age-related macular degeneration (AMD). This finding was significant with a p-value of 0.016 in the context of 97 subjects assessed for drusen, thereby supporting its relevance in the genetic architecture of AMD.
title: Systemic and Genetic Risk Factors for Reticular Macular Disease and Soft Drusen in Age-Related Macular Degeneration

finding: Associated with hypothyroidism and TSH levels, rs2983511 contributed to the broader understanding of thyroid disorders.
title: Uncovering the Shared Genetic Components of Thyroid Disorders and Reproductive Health

finding: Showed a correlation with hemochromatosis and had a strong significant association with blood donorship in the study.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals the unique genetic structure of active blood donors

finding: Strong association found with blood donorship in the HLA-DQA1 gene, although significance decreased after adjusting for T1D.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals the unique genetic structure of active blood donors

finding: The minor C-allele at rs2504706 was associated with a higher intake of cereal (regression coefficient 0.058, P=2.94E-13) and a lower intake of coffee (regression coefficient -0.034, P=1.67E-09). This finding contributed to the understanding of dietary preferences related to cereal and coffee consumption.
title: Increased brain volume from cereal, decreased brain volume from coffee -- shared genetic determinants and impacts on cognitive function, body mass index (BMI) and other metabolic measures: cohort study of UK Biobank participants

finding: The locus at HLA-DQB1 contained the index SNP rs3844313, which showed a significant association with AMD (OR = 1.41), particularly strong in individuals of African ancestry.
title: Distinctive cross-ancestry genetic architecture for age-related macular degeneration

finding: Located near the PHACTR1/EDN1 locus, this variant was associated with CAD and showcased significant functional annotations.
title: Discovery and systematic characterization of risk variants and genes for coronary artery disease in over a million participants

finding: The SNP rs13195636 was identified as an influential outlier in the schizophrenia GWAS and contributed significantly to various results on differential white blood cell counts. Specifically, the presence of this SNP was linked to elevated lymphocyte count (beta=0.014; FDR adjusted p-val=0.010), monocyte count (beta=0.009; FDR adjusted p-val=0.045), and neutrophil count (beta=0.011; FDR adjusted p-val=0.028) in schizophrenia patients. It was located in the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) on chromosome 6, known for its critical roles in neurodevelopment and immune regulation, and was the strongest SNP reported by the Psychiatric Genomics Consortium (PGC) for schizophrenia.
title: Bidirectional two-sample Mendelian randomization study of differential white blood cell count and schizophrenia

finding: The rs1799971 (A118G) variant in the OPRM1 gene showed a genome-wide significant association with opioid addiction (OA), with discovery p = 1.51 × 10^-8 and replication p = 0.049. However, further analysis suggested that this particular variant might not be the primary driver of the locus's overall association with OA.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study of opioid addiction: OPRM1 and Beyond

finding: The lead SNP rs9478500 was associated with increased risk of OA, showcasing the strongest evidence to date for variants in the OPRM1 gene, with a significance level of p = 2.56 × 10^-9.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association study of opioid addiction: OPRM1 and Beyond

finding: The SNP <italic>rs11308001</italic> was linked to hair color (natural, before greying), particularly with associations specific to hair color heterogeneity among various ancestry groups.
title: Inter-population differences of allele frequency and regulome tagging are associated with the heterogeneity of loci identified by cross-ancestry genome-wide association studies

finding: The rs75932628 SNP, which leads to the R47H variant, was associated with TREM2 dysfunction impacting cell surface expression and shedding of sTREM2. It was notably linked to the TREM2 risk variant group, which significantly contributed to our understanding of neurodegeneration in Alzheimer's disease (AD).
title: Alterations in the Brain Lipidome of Alzheimer’s Disease Donors with Rare TREM2 Risk Variants

finding: The rs2234255 SNP, corresponding to the H157Y variant, was believed to affect α-secretase cleavage and production of sTREM2. This variant was part of the TREM2 risk variants that increased the likelihood of developing AD, highlighting its relevance in the context of TREM2 functionality.
title: Alterations in the Brain Lipidome of Alzheimer’s Disease Donors with Rare TREM2 Risk Variants

finding: This SNP was associated with cg05831784 near HAO1, highlighting its connection to diabetic kidney disease (DKD).
title: Blood methylation biomarkers are associated with diabetic kidney disease progression in type 1 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs4580892 was identified as a top signal in the shared genetic architecture between type 2 diabetes (T2D) and fracture. The rs4580892_T allele was associated with an increased risk of T2D (OR=1.041, P=8.46×10⁻⁹) and a decreased risk of fracture (OR=0.944, P=3.68×10⁻¹⁰). This finding indicated an inverse relationship, suggesting that while the genetic predisposition for T2D was linked to higher bone mineral density (BMD), it concurrently posed a lower fracture risk.
title: Deciphering the relationship between type 2 diabetes and fracture risk: the genetic and observational evidences

finding: The rs9349379 variant was recognized as a common non-coding variant in the third intron of the PHACTR1 gene and was identified by a study as the causal variant for associations with five vascular diseases. This finding suggested a mechanism through distal regulatory effects on the endothelial gene EDN1, which is located 600 kb upstream of PHACTR1. TargetAge confirmed this association through cluster 644, linking rs9349379 to cardiovascular conditions such as coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and coronary atherosclerosis. Additionally, PHACTR1 was further implicated in other conditions such as ischemic stroke and large artery stroke.
title: Integrative analysis of GWAS and co-localisation data suggests novel genes associated with age-related multimorbidity

finding: This SNP was also one of the 58 significant loci linked to anxiety and showed elevated associations with other phenotypes, particularly in cardiometabolic outcomes.
title: Genome-wide association study of major anxiety disorders in 122,341 European-ancestry cases identifies 58 loci and highlights GABAergic signaling

finding: The SNP rs4580892 was identified as a top signal in the intron of the RSPO3 gene, indicating a significant association with both type 2 diabetes and fracture risk. Specifically, the T allele of rs4580892 was associated with increased risk of type 2 diabetes (OR=1.0412, P=8.46x10^-9) and decreased fracture risk (OR=0.944, P=3.68x10^-10), suggesting an inverse relationship between these two conditions.
title: Type 2 diabetes and fracture risk: deciphering the complex relationship with both genetic and observational evidence

finding: The variant rs199585353 in the gene PRIM2 was associated with ischemic stroke in European Caucasians, displaying a minor allele frequency of 0.25% in cases and absent in controls. This finding highlighted a significant association with a p-value of 8.28 × 10−8.
title: Exome Array Analysis of 9,721 ischemic stroke cases from the SiGN Consortium

finding: The MEP1A variant rs62619974 was significantly associated with ischemic stroke at p < 1 × 10−10, again observed more frequently among African American stroke cases.
title: Exome Array Analysis of 9,721 ischemic stroke cases from the SiGN Consortium

finding: rs3129888 was found to be a significant risk variant for sarcoidosis in both European American and African American populations, located in an intron of the HLA-DRA gene. The G allele of this SNP increased risk and correlated with previous studies on Lofgren's syndrome.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies multiple HLA loci for sarcoidosis susceptibility

finding: Identified as the most significant SNP associated with sarcoidosis, rs9269233 was found to be an independent risk allele with a strong association while affecting HLA-DRB9 gene expression.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies multiple HLA loci for sarcoidosis susceptibility

finding: This SNP was nominally significant in both European and African American populations in previous studies, reflecting an association with sarcoidosis risk, although it did not meet genome-wide significance in this study.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies multiple HLA loci for sarcoidosis susceptibility

finding: A novel risk variant for sarcoidosis, rs35656642 showed strong association in both populations studied and has not been previously documented.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies multiple HLA loci for sarcoidosis susceptibility

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with sarcoidosis and acted as an eQTL for expression of HLA-DQA1.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies multiple HLA loci for sarcoidosis susceptibility

finding: Found to be significant in relation to sarcoidosis risk, with strong associations demonstrated in both cohorts.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies multiple HLA loci for sarcoidosis susceptibility

finding: Originally associated with unclassified heart failure, this SNP (CDKN1A) showed significant genetic associations in MVP African Americans even after correction for multiple tests.
title: Genetic Architecture of Heart Failure with Preserved versus Reduced Ejection Fraction

finding: This SNP (CDKN1A) also showed significant genetic effects in the stated cohort confirming its relevance.
title: Genetic Architecture of Heart Failure with Preserved versus Reduced Ejection Fraction

finding: The SNP rs71557378 was associated with suicide attempt and reached genome-wide significance with a p-value of 1.97×10⁻⁸. This finding was derived from the International Suicide Genetics Consortium's meta-analysis involving a substantial number of cases.
title: Genome-wide association study meta-analysis of suicide attempt in 43,871 cases identifies twelve genome-wide significant loci

finding: The SNP rs1800562 corresponds to the HFE p.C282Y genotype, which was the focus of the analysis. In male p.C282Y homozygotes, it was found that higher iron polygenic risk scores significantly increased the risk of liver fibrosis, cirrhosis, and liver cancer.
title: Penetrance of HFE haemochromatosis variants to clinical disease: polygenic risk score associations in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs1799945 refers to the HFE p.H63D genotype. It was analyzed alongside p.C282Y, where associations were observed indicating that it contributed to disease penetrance in p.C282Y/p.H63D compound heterozygotes with regards to the related diseases.
title: Penetrance of HFE haemochromatosis variants to clinical disease: polygenic risk score associations in UK Biobank

finding: This variant was negatively associated with blood donation and was previously linked to spondylopathies and celiac disease.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals the unique genetic structure of active blood donors

finding: rs3130906 was negatively associated with blood donorship and had prior associations with spondylopathies and celiac disease.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals the unique genetic structure of active blood donors

finding: This SNP was negatively associated with blood donorship and is linked to both spondylopathies and celiac disease.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals the unique genetic structure of active blood donors

finding: This variant, enriched in hemochromatosis patients, exhibited a moderate positive effect on hemoglobin levels, indicating its role in iron metabolism and blood donation eligibility.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals the unique genetic structure of active blood donors

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with blood donorship and positively influenced the expression of HLA-DRA, while showing a higher variance among blood donors that might relate to autoimmunity.
title: Genome-wide association study reveals the unique genetic structure of active blood donors

finding: The SNP rs487152, which tagged the locus SLC22A3/LPA, was strongly associated with increased serum lipoprotein A (Lp(a)) levels in the UK Biobank. This association was quantified with a genome-wide association study p-value of P=4.06×10<sup>−1586</sup>. Although this finding was significant, the underlying mechanism relating increased Lp(a) levels to insulin deficiency in type 2 diabetes (T2D) was reported to be unknown, indicating a complex interplay in cardiometabolic conditions.
title: High-throughput Genetic Clustering of Type 2 Diabetes Loci Reveals Heterogeneous Mechanistic Pathways of Metabolic Disease

finding: This variant was linked to olfactory bulb volume and exhibited a significant difference in effect size across sexes (females: β = 0.01, males: β = 0.06, P = 1.17 x 10^-3), implicating it in sexual dimorphism in neuroanatomical characteristics.
title: Genome-wide analysis identifies 66 variants underlying anatomical variation in human neuroendocrine structures and reveals links to testosterone

finding: An intronic variant of CENPW associated with pituitary gland volume (β = 0.16). Its prior connection to male-pattern baldness linked it to testosterone-related phenotypes.
title: Genome-wide analysis identifies 66 variants underlying anatomical variation in human neuroendocrine structures and reveals links to testosterone

finding: The SNP rs1799964 was linked to a differential response associated with the Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha gene in the context of Zika virus infection, indicating its potential role as a modifier of neurodevelopmental outcomes in affected infants.
title: Building a growing genomic data repository for maternal and fetal health through the PING Consortium

finding: The SNP rs1235162 at the UBD-SNORD32B locus was newly identified in this study and was associated with habitual coffee consumption.
title: Habitual Coffee Consumption Increases Risks for Metabolic Diseases: Genome-wide Association Studies and a Phenotype-wide Two Sample Mendelian Randomization Analysis

finding: The SNP rs4713916 was identified as a potential genetic predictor of varying responses to inhaled corticosteroids among patients with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). This finding was referenced in a study by Russo et al. (2019), indicating that genetic variation at this locus could influence therapeutic effectiveness in a clinical setting, thereby contributing to personalized medicine approaches in COPD management.
title: Anomalous epithelial variations and ectopic inflammatory response in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

finding: This variant was identified as the only SNP exhibiting a strong effect size of 0.334, which indicates significant positive association with blood pressure (BP) traits.
title: CLUSTERING OF RARE VARIANTS FOR CAUSAL VARIANTS IDENTIFICATION AND EFFECT DIRECTION CLASSIFICATION

finding: Similar to rs201955087, this SNP was grouped into a signal cluster with a moderate positive effect size of 0.173, suggesting it may have a positive association with blood pressure (BP) traits.
title: CLUSTERING OF RARE VARIANTS FOR CAUSAL VARIANTS IDENTIFICATION AND EFFECT DIRECTION CLASSIFICATION

finding: This SNP contributed to the signal cluster with a moderate positive effect size of 0.173, indicating a potential positive effect associated with BP traits.
title: CLUSTERING OF RARE VARIANTS FOR CAUSAL VARIANTS IDENTIFICATION AND EFFECT DIRECTION CLASSIFICATION

finding: This variant was also within the moderate positive effect size cluster of 0.173, suggesting a positive influence on blood pressure (BP) traits.
title: CLUSTERING OF RARE VARIANTS FOR CAUSAL VARIANTS IDENTIFICATION AND EFFECT DIRECTION CLASSIFICATION

finding: This SNP was included in the signal cluster with a moderate positive effect size of 0.173, indicating a possible positive relationship with blood pressure (BP) traits.
title: CLUSTERING OF RARE VARIANTS FOR CAUSAL VARIANTS IDENTIFICATION AND EFFECT DIRECTION CLASSIFICATION

finding: This SNP was identified as associated with acetate levels in South Asians, representing a novel association as it had no prior linkage to acetate or any known traits.
title: Metabolic Drivers of Dysglycemia in Pregnancy: Ethnic-Specific GWAS of 146 Metabolites and 1-Sample Mendelian Randomisation Analyses in a UK Multi-Ethnic Birth Cohort

finding: A significant association was identified with tau deposition in Alzheimer's disease, showing a genome-wide association with tau-SUVR levels (P=5.76×10^-10), implicating the gene JARID2. This association remained significant after adjusting for APOE-ε4 dosage.
title: Genome-wide scan of Flortaucipir PET levels finds JARID2 associated with cerebral tau deposition

finding: The minor T-allele of SNP rs2523425 exerted risk on SS by decreasing TRIM27 gene expression. This finding indicated that genetic variants impacting TRIM27 expression could increase the likelihood of systemic autoimmune diseases, including SS.
title: An integrative multi-omics approach in Sjögren’s Syndrome identifies novel genetic drivers with regulatory function and disease-specificity

finding: The minor T-allele of SNP rs7769693 was associated with increased SS risk and decreased methylation levels at the PSMB8 gene, implicating that the variant could exert its pathogenic role through hypomethylation in this context.
title: An integrative multi-omics approach in Sjögren’s Syndrome identifies novel genetic drivers with regulatory function and disease-specificity

finding: The variant rs9349379 in PHACTR1 had a PIP of 1.00, affirming its strong association with migraine risk and indicating its potential causality.
title: Fine-mapping a genome-wide meta-analysis of 98,374 migraine cases identifies 181 sets of candidate causal variants

finding: The SNP rs78459872 exhibited GWS effects on smoking cessation (SC) depending on whether the individual was a late-onset or early-onset smoker, indicating the presence of heterogeneous effects for smoking behaviors.
title: Investigating heterogeneous genetic effects contributing to smoking behaviors

finding: The SNP rs2941 was found to be associated with increased asthma susceptibility, severity, and exacerbations. It was one of the primary SNPs studied in relation to PGAP3 and asthma, similar to rs2517.
title: PGAP3 regulates human bronchial epithelial cell mRNAs present in asthma and respiratory virus reference data sets

finding: The variant rs3798220, a missense variant in the LPA gene, was associated with 1.18 attributable DALYs mainly through ischemic heart disease. The effect size was measured with a 95% confidence interval of 1.03-1.32, and the statistical significance was high (<P=1.3×10^-58>). This finding highlighted the importance of considering ischemic heart disease when evaluating overall disease burden from genetic variants.
title: Genetic risk factors have a substantial impact on healthy life years

finding: In the context of autoimmune diseases, specifically in association with seronegative rheumatoid arthritis (RA), the marker rs145575084, located within the MICA gene, showed the strongest association. This finding underscored a linkage between the HLA B*27:05 allele and SNP markers from HLA-C to MICA, highlighting the interrelatedness of these genetic factors in disease susceptibility.
title: Phenome-wide HLA association study of Finnish biobank participants reveals infection-autoimmune disease links and modifier effects between HLA genes and alleles

finding: The TSH-increasing allele of rs1743963 was associated with decreased risk of both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism. It was also linked to increased calcium levels.
title: Genome-wide association study of thyroid-stimulating hormone highlights new genes, pathways and associations with thyroid disease susceptibility and age-of-onset

finding: This SNP was implicated in psoriatic arthritis, showing similar lambda_gc-adjusted p-values, odds ratios, and directions of effect in both the 'both-controls' GWAS and the 'internal-controls' GWAS, marking it as a significant locus.
title: Accurate cross-platform GWAS analysis via two-stage imputation

finding: Similar to rs36058333, this SNP also showed replication across the 'both-controls' GWAS and 'internal-controls' GWAS, indicating its association with psoriatic arthritis.
title: Accurate cross-platform GWAS analysis via two-stage imputation

finding: Identified in the 'both-controls' scenario, this SNP was recognized as significant in relation to psoriatic arthritis, further corroborated by analyses conducted with the 'internal-controls' cohort.
title: Accurate cross-platform GWAS analysis via two-stage imputation

finding: This SNP achieved genome-wide significance in the context of psoriatic arthritis within the 'both-controls' GWAS, illustrating its strong association with the disease.
title: Accurate cross-platform GWAS analysis via two-stage imputation

finding: This SNP replicated results from a published meta-analysis, observed in both the 'TSIM Joint' and 'TSIM Meta' analyses of European pSSNS cohorts.
title: Accurate cross-platform GWAS analysis via two-stage imputation

finding: Successfully replicated in both 'TSIM Joint' and 'TSIM Meta' analyses of European cohorts, showing its association with the condition under study.
title: Accurate cross-platform GWAS analysis via two-stage imputation

finding: Recognized in both 'TSIM Joint' and 'TSIM Meta' analyses and proved to be significant, contributing to understanding the genetic landscape of pSSNS.
title: Accurate cross-platform GWAS analysis via two-stage imputation

finding: The genetic variant rs13191659 was associated with both Multiple Sclerosis (MS) and falls, indicating a shared genetic effect. It was implicated in the context of the LINC00240 gene, which is related to iron status biomarkers, representing a potential link between MS and the risk of falls.
title: Pleiotropic Genetic Effects between Multiple Sclerosis and Musculoskeletal Traits

finding: The rs2023239-A/G polymorphism was found to be significantly associated with the risk for schizophrenia-spectrum disorders (SSD). Individuals carrying the G allele had a protective effect against SSD, showing a higher presence of G-allele carriers among healthy controls compared to patients. Furthermore, it was reported that higher scores in the Pattern Intensity Index (PII) correlated with lower SSD risk in G-allele carriers, while AA-homozygotes showed an inverse relationship.
title: Genetic and neurodevelopmental markers in schizophrenia-spectrum disorders: analysis of the combined role of the Cannabinoid Receptor 1 gene (CNR1) and dermatoglyphics

finding: The rs806379-A/T polymorphism was associated with an increased risk for SSD. It was observed that T-allele carriers were overrepresented among SSD patients compared to healthy controls. This SNP influenced the Total A-B Ridge Count (TABRC) whereby T-allele carriers exhibited lower ridge counts compared to AA-homozygotes, suggesting that it plays a role in SSD vulnerability.
title: Genetic and neurodevelopmental markers in schizophrenia-spectrum disorders: analysis of the combined role of the Cannabinoid Receptor 1 gene (CNR1) and dermatoglyphics

finding: This SNP was identified as causal to 6 trait pairs related to abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and cardiometabolic traits. It was noted to be involved in lipid metabolism processes.
title: Shared Genetic Susceptibility between Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm and Cardiometabolic Traits

finding: This SNP was found to be shared among 4 trait pairs linked to AAA, indicating potential genetic overlap with other cardiovascular traits.
title: Shared Genetic Susceptibility between Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm and Cardiometabolic Traits

finding: The SNP was identified as being shared among 3 trait pairs associated with AAA, suggesting a role in lipid-related genetic pathways.
title: Shared Genetic Susceptibility between Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm and Cardiometabolic Traits

finding: The TNF gene containing SNP rs361525 was recognized as a factor influencing liver disease risk, probably through its involvement in inflammatory pathways.
title: Studies to develop a glucagon sensitivity test in humans: The GLUSENTIC study protocol

finding: The SNP rs9376090 was significantly associated with childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) at the 6q23 locus with a P-value of 8.23 x 10^-9 and an odds ratio (OR) of 1.27. This association was primarily driven by non-Latino White individuals due to their larger sample size.
title: Genome-wide trans-ethnic meta-analysis identifies novel susceptibility loci for childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia

finding: The SNP rs7761208 was linked to the PREP gene and showed significant association with chronic dry cough that met a Bonferroni correction threshold. It was previously noted in relation to ACEi-induced cough.
title: Genomics of chronic cough unravels neurological pathways

finding: The SNP rs62431527 demonstrated strong colocalization with ovarian cancer, suggesting its involvement in cancer risk.
title: Enhancer RNA transcriptome-wide association study reveals an atlas of pan-cancer susceptibility eRNAs

finding: The SNP rs9503939 was noted for showing significant association with non-cognitive measures and was also indicated to have suggestive associations with CSF amyloid-β levels.
title: Genome Wide Analysis Across Alzheimer’s Disease Endophenotypes: Main Effects and Stage Specific Interactions

finding: Located in the 3' UTR of BACH2, this SNP was identified as having neuroprotective associations, especially with measures of cortical thickness.
title: Genome Wide Analysis Across Alzheimer’s Disease Endophenotypes: Main Effects and Stage Specific Interactions

finding: Located near HLA-B, this SNP maintained study wide significance in cognitive measures, despite evidence suggesting reduced significance when adjusting for APOE allele status.
title: Genome Wide Analysis Across Alzheimer’s Disease Endophenotypes: Main Effects and Stage Specific Interactions

finding: This SNP, located near HLA-DPB1, also retained significance in cognitive measures under study conditions evaluating HLA effects.
title: Genome Wide Analysis Across Alzheimer’s Disease Endophenotypes: Main Effects and Stage Specific Interactions

finding: This variant mapped to chromosome 6 at the ESR1 locus was significantly associated with having any TP53 mutation, and showed multiple significant associations with TP53 gain of function mutations in the multi-ancestry validation and MyBrCa studies.
title: Association of ESR1 germline variants with TP53 somatic variants in breast tumors in a genome-wide study

finding: Associated with TP53 mutations with a P value of 2.8 x 10^(-7) in the MyBrCa study.
title: Association of ESR1 germline variants with TP53 somatic variants in breast tumors in a genome-wide study

finding: The signal for rs374248993 was in linkage disequilibrium with an amino acid change in HLA-DRB1, involving a threonine to arginine change at codon 233, which was associated with a decreased risk of chronic sputum production (OR 0.91, P=3.43×10⁻⁹).
title: Genome-wide association study of chronic sputum production implicates loci involved in mucus production and infection

finding: The SNP rs13195402 was associated with bipolar disorder (BD) at genome-wide significance. It was identified as a missense variant in the gene BTN2A1, which is expressed in the brain and encodes a plasma membrane protein. This association was notable as it occurred distally to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) genes, differentiating it from associations found in schizophrenia where structural alleles of the C4 gene were influential.
title: Genome-wide association study of over 40,000 bipolar disorder cases provides new insights into the underlying biology

finding: The rs139586367 variant in UFL1 was identified as having a very high odds ratio of 284.06 linked with lymphoid neoplasms, indicating its strong association with multiple cancers.
title: Assessment of Genetic Susceptibility to Multiple Primary Cancers through Whole-Exome Sequencing in Two Large Multi-Ancestry Studies

finding: The lead SNP rs2790102 in the RUNX2 gene was identified with genome-wide significance (p=8.92x10^-9), associating with a decrease of 0.15 years in BAG. This SNP confirmed findings from previous research suggesting its relevance in brain health.
title: Genetic architecture of brain age and its casual relations with brain and mental disorders

finding: The variant rs487152, located at the SLC22A3/LPA locus, was strongly associated with increased serum lipoprotein A (Lp(a)) levels in the UK Biobank, with a GWAS p-value of P=4.06×10−1586. Moreover, it was noted that this locus was associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes (T2D), although the underlying mechanism related to insulin deficiency remained unclear.
title: High-throughput Genetic Clustering of Type 2 Diabetes Loci Reveals Heterogeneous Mechanistic Pathways of Metabolic Disease

finding: The IL17A rs2275913 minor allele variant was identified as a risk factor for fibrosis progression in MASLD patients, where individuals carrying the minor allele A/A and A/G exhibited increased liver stiffness and more severe fibrosis compared to those with the homozygous major allele G/G. Additionally, IL-17A levels in response to fungal stimulation were significantly higher in T cells from carriers of the minor allele, correlating with elevated Th17/rTreg ratios in peripheral blood, indicating a predisposition to developing metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH).
title: Mycobiome Dysbiosis and Genetic Predisposition for Elevated IL-17A Drive Fibrosis in MASLD

finding: The rare variant rs144171242 at the 6p21.1 locus was associated with PUV (OR 7.20; P=2.02x10^-8) and was located in an intron of the PTK7 gene. The variant's effect was stronger in South Asians, providing insights into its regulatory role in embryonic patterning.
title: Mixed ancestry analysis of whole-genome sequencing reveals common, rare, and structural variants associated with posterior urethral valves

finding: The SNP rs2230926, within the TNFAIP3 gene, significantly increased the production of neutrophil extracellular traps and citrullinated epitopes, implicating it as a risk factor for SLE.
title: A multilayered post-GWAS analysis pipeline defines functional variants and target genes for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

finding: The SNP rs72856706, located in the intronic region of the CCHCR1 gene, was significantly associated with COVID-19 critical illness, showing a BETA of 0.614 and a P value of 9.15E-18. This finding provided support for a causal link between testosterone levels and COVID-19 critical illness severity. Additionally, this variant also demonstrated significant association with serum testosterone levels (BETA=0.029, P=7.307E-09) and showed relevance in other related phenotypes, although it was not significant for COVID-19 respiratory failure.
title: Genetically determined serum testosterone level and Covid-19 illness level: A mendelian randomization study

finding: This intronic variant near PRIM2BP was associated with olfactory bulb volume (females: β = 0.01, SE = 0.01; males: β = 0.06, SE = 0.01) and exhibited a significant sex difference in effect size (P = 1.17 × 10⁻³).
title: Genome-wide analysis identifies 66 variants underlying anatomical variation in human neuroendocrine structures and reveals links to testosterone

finding: A downstream intronic variant of CENPW, this SNP showed a significant association with pituitary gland volume (β = 0.16, SE = 0.007) and was linked to male-pattern baldness, related to testosterone.
title: Genome-wide analysis identifies 66 variants underlying anatomical variation in human neuroendocrine structures and reveals links to testosterone

finding: The SNP rs473267, linked to both the DOPEY1 and PGM3 genes, was found to be a novel anxiety locus and shared with schizophrenia, indicating potential shared genetic underpinnings.
title: Identification of Novel Genomic Loci for Anxiety and Extensive Genetic Overlap with Psychiatric Disorders

finding: The variant rs2229523 (G>A) was identified as a cis-pQTL for CD73. The A allele was associated with higher plasma levels of CD73, echoing previously observed associations where the G allele decreased NT5E mRNA expression in blood, indicating potential impact on CD73 protein levels.
title: Common variation in a long non-coding RNA gene modulates variation of circulating TGF-β2 levels in metastatic colorectal cancer patients (Alliance)

finding: The variant rs7767396 (A>G) was validated as a cis-pQTL for circulating VEGF-A in advanced pancreatic cancer. It was re-confirmed in mCRC patients with a P-value less than 2.6e-12 indicating its strong association with VEGF-A protein levels.
title: Common variation in a long non-coding RNA gene modulates variation of circulating TGF-β2 levels in metastatic colorectal cancer patients (Alliance)

finding: The SNP rs3798220, within the LPA gene, displayed significant association with P<sub>MTAG_HF</sub> = 6.74×10<sup>-51</sup>, qualifying it as a positive original finding.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide analysis identified novel risk loci and candidate drugs for heart failure

finding: The rs6902687 SNP at the ZSCAN23 locus reached genome-wide significance with a p-value of 1.5 x 10^-8 and was associated with the expression of ZSCAN23 in pancreatic tissue, suggesting its role in longevity.
title: Genetic associations with human longevity are enriched for oncogenic genes

finding: The rs13190937 SNP within ZSCAN23 also demonstrated a significant (p = 1.5 x 10^-8) association with longevity and was linked to increased expression of ZSCAN23 in pancreatic tissue as an eQTL.
title: Genetic associations with human longevity are enriched for oncogenic genes

finding: The noncoding variant rs557011 was associated with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection. This variant was mentioned in relation to the HLA class II allele DQA1*03, which was previously reported by Sveinbjornsson et al. as being associated with Mtb infection. The identification of this SNP highlighted the potential influence of genetic variants located between HLA alleles on susceptibility to Mtb.
title: Expression of specific HLA class II alleles is associated with an increased risk for active tuberculosis and a distinct gene expression profile

finding: The SNP rs62401887 was associated with the hepatic BAG and mapped to the MRS2 gene. This SNP exhibited a deleterious score of 14.89 and demonstrated significant eQTL association with a P-value of 1.09×10^-10.
title: The Genetic Architecture of Biological Age in Nine Human Organ Systems

finding: Association of rs11545686, which served as a proxy for HLA-DQA1*03:02, was confirmed with susceptibility to MPO-AAV and MPA in the Japanese population with a P value of 5.8×10^-7 and an odds ratio of 1.74.
title: Association of HLA-class II alleles with risk of relapse in myeloperoxidase-antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody positive vasculitis in the Japanese population

finding: The SNP rs3798220, mapped to the LPA gene, had a P MTAG HF of 6.74×10^-51 and was associated with heart failure.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide analysis identified novel risk loci and candidate drugs for heart failure

finding: The ECHDC1 variant was associated with ethylmalonate levels, indicating its relevance in fatty acid metabolism.
title: Genome-wide association study of 1,391 plasma metabolites in 6,136 Finnish men identifies 303 novel signals and provides biological insights into human diseases

finding: The PCMT1 variant was associated with S-adenosylhomocysteine levels, important in methylation reactions.
title: Genome-wide association study of 1,391 plasma metabolites in 6,136 Finnish men identifies 303 novel signals and provides biological insights into human diseases

finding: The variant rs9322319 near the RMND1 gene exhibited significant association with endometriosis, with a P-value of 2.86E-08.
title: Expanding the genetic landscape of endometriosis: Integrative -omics analyses uncover key pathways from a multi-ancestry study of over 900,000 women

finding: The SNP rs2235215 near MYLIP was associated with post-translational LDLR degradation, underlining its importance in cholesterol regulation.
title: Lipo-proteomic and metabolic fine-mapping of genetic lipid risk loci

finding: The top lead SNP was associated with the hepatic biological age gap (BAG) and mapped to the MRS2 gene, which is involved in magnesium ion transmembrane transporter activity. The deleterious score was reported as 14.89 with an expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) P-value of 1.09×10−10, indicating significant functional relevance.
title: The Genetic Architecture of Biological Age in Nine Human Organ Systems

finding: The SNP rs56076919 was found to be significantly associated with knee pain, with a p-value of 9.82 × 10^-12 in the primary GWAS and a strong replication p-value of 3.61 × 10^-5. This SNP maps to the COL11A2 gene, which is involved in collagen structure, indicating a potential role in knee pain related to cartilage integrity.
title: A Genome-wide Association Study Identifies Novel Genetic Variants Associated with Knee Pain in the UK Biobank (N = 441,757)

finding: SNP rs687878 showed a primary GWAS p-value of 2.38 × 10^-8 and a replicated p-value of 1.36 × 10^-3. Known to be involved with SUPT3H, its association indicates a relationship with cartilage degradation processes pertinent to knee pain.
title: A Genome-wide Association Study Identifies Novel Genetic Variants Associated with Knee Pain in the UK Biobank (N = 441,757)

finding: The SNP rs17587 was statistically significant for the association with asthma, suggesting that it may have a role in the disease's etiology. Furthermore, it was proposed to increase the risk of rheumatoid arthritis among the Han Chinese ethnicity from Yunnan and to be associated with vitiligo in the Saudi community, indicating potential shared mechanisms between asthma and other autoimmune diseases.
title: PWAS Hub: Exploring Gene-Based Associations of Common Complex Diseases

finding: The analysis revealed that leaving out rs13195401 also resulted in a statistically significant causal effect estimate on bipolar disorder (BD), reporting a beta of 0.031 with a p-value of 0.041. This finding indicated that rs13195401 contributed meaningfully to the relationship between BD and its association with poverty.
title: The impact of poverty on mental illness: Emerging evidence of a causal relationship

finding: The SNP rs988551 in LAMA2 was identified as significantly associated with gestational hypertension, showing a P-value of 4.7×10−9 in a meta-analysis involving 5,636 Europeans, 1,278 Africans, and 759 Admixed Americans. It was also associated with other hypertension-related traits, with P-values less than 1×10−3.
title: Searching and visualizing genetic associations of pregnancy traits by using GnuMoM2b

finding: The SNP rs9349050 was identified as a significant instrumental variable in the Mendelian Randomization analysis, demonstrating a potential genetic link between MDGA1, a cell surface glycoprotein, and the metabolite 1-Arachidonoylglycerol (1-AG). Variations in rs9349050 distinguished MDGA1 and 1-AG levels in individuals carrying different genotypes, suggesting a genetic basis for the co-regulation of proteins and metabolites.
title: Longitudinal analysis of genetic and environmental interplay in human metabolic profiles and the implication for metabolic health

finding: The study reported that the rs10455872 locus was involved in the pathogenesis of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Specifically, it was highlighted during the iterative process of GCTA COJO analysis, where it was noted that this locus contributed to the identification of a minimum number of independently, genome-wide significant SNPs after a maximum of four iterations. This indicated its significance in the genetic architecture of AAA, reflecting broader mechanisms including lipid metabolism and vascular development.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS deciphers genetic architecture of abdominal aortic aneurysm and highlights PCSK9 as a therapeutic target

finding: The SNP rs1800629, related to the TNF-α gene, was found to have a significant impact on cognitive impairment in Asian breast cancer patients, indicating its potential involvement in cognitive decline, which may relate to immune response observed in aMCI.
title: Is amnestic mild cognitive impairment a neuro-immune condition?

finding: The CCHCR1 stop gain variant rs3130453 exhibited a marginal association with increased risk of psoriasis (OR=1.49, pval=7.7e-20). Its effect increased significantly when combined with two minor alleles of MUC22 (OR=3.2) and HSPA1L (OR=3.1). This indicated a synergistic epistatic relationship affecting disease risk.
title: Atlas of epistasis

finding: The MUC22 missense variant rs3094672 was part of a synergistic epistatic interaction with rs3130453, leading to an increased risk for psoriasis as its presence augmented the effect of the CCHCR1 variant on disease risk (OR from 1.49 to 3.2).
title: Atlas of epistasis

finding: The HSPA1L missense variant rs2227956 also showed synergistic epistasis with CCHCR1's rs3130453, enhancing its effect on psoriasis risk, resulting in an overall OR of 3.1 in the presence of two minor alleles.
title: Atlas of epistasis

finding: The LTA missense variant rs2229094 demonstrated an antagonistic epistatic effect with rs2272596, affecting psoriasis risk oppositely depending on its presence. It was associated with both increased and decreased disease risk based on the co-allele of rs2272596.
title: Atlas of epistasis

finding: The SNP rs1359232 was linked to the MECPP_MEHPP ratio, with an effect size of -0.134 and a highly significant p-value of 4.58E-17, associated with the SLC17A1 gene.
title: Common genetic variants associated with urinary phthalate levels in children: a genome-wide study

finding: The SNP rs6921438 showed a strong association with VEGF levels in maternal serum at both visits, with p-values of 7.94×10^-30 and 2.49×10^-28 for visit 1 and visit 2, respectively. It was located near the VEGFA gene and confirmed previous associations between the VEGFA locus and circulating VEGF levels.
title: Genetic Associations with Dynamic Placental Proteins Identify Causal Biomarkers for Hypertension in Pregnancy

finding: The SNP rs7766070, an intronic variant within the CDKAL1 gene, showed a significant association with GDM risk, with an OR of 1.27 (95% CI 1.18, 1.35) and a p-value of 8.07×10-12, indicating a notable genetic influence on GDM susceptibility.
title: Genome-wide association and Mendelian randomisation analysis among 30,699 Chinese pregnant women identifies novel genetic and molecular risk factors for gestational diabetes and glycaemic traits

finding: The SNP rs145348074 was also significantly associated with CI-free survival time, reflecting a hazard ratio (HR) similar to the findings of rs146729640 in both Amish and NIA-LOAD cohorts, supporting the notion of a delayed onset of cognitive impairment.
title: Genetic variants in the SHISA6 gene are associated with delayed cognitive impairment in two family datasets

finding: The SNP rs706954, located <5kb downstream of VGLL2, was associated with significant interaction effects with periconceptional alcohol use, exhibiting a p-value of 4.62×10^-6. The minor allele (G) increased the odds of non-syndromic cleft lip with or without cleft palate (NSCL/P) for individuals with alcohol exposure but decreased the odds for those without.
title: Genome-wide interaction study implicates VGLL2 and alcohol exposure and PRL and smoking in orofacial cleft risk

finding: The SNP rs35097027, located at the 6p22.3 locus, showed significant interactions with maternal smoking, with a geo p-value of 1.96×10^-5. The minor allele (C) was associated with increased odds of NSCL/P among individuals exposed to maternal smoking, compared to lower odds in individuals without this exposure.
title: Genome-wide interaction study implicates VGLL2 and alcohol exposure and PRL and smoking in orofacial cleft risk

finding: At the 6q21 locus, SNP rs6929494 had significant GE interaction with alcohol exposure, with a p-value of 1.18×10^-5. The major allele (A) increased the odds of NSCL/P for those exposed to alcohol but offered a protective effect for non-exposed individuals.
title: Genome-wide interaction study implicates VGLL2 and alcohol exposure and PRL and smoking in orofacial cleft risk

finding: SNP rs117083 was associated with a strong interaction with periconceptional alcohol use, where the estimated odds of NSCL/P were 2.73 times higher for each copy of the minor allele (G) among alcohol users, while presenting a 35% reduction in odds for non-users.
title: Genome-wide interaction study implicates VGLL2 and alcohol exposure and PRL and smoking in orofacial cleft risk

finding: The SNP rs72959041 in RSPO3 demonstrated the strongest association with GFATadjBMI (P = 3.2 x 10^-32) and was clarified as a causal variant affecting various fat distributions, promoting an increase in VAT with a decrease in GFAT.
title: Inherited basis of visceral, abdominal subcutaneous and gluteofemoral fat depots

finding: The SNP rs73727916 was associated with the pertussis toxin (PT) antibody response, explaining the variance in levels of immunoglobulin G (IgG) following vaccination, with a beta coefficient of 0.33 and a P-value of 1.9 x 10^-27, indicating a strong positive finding.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: The SNP rs34951355 was linked to the diphtheria toxin (DT) response, being the primary variant associated with this vaccine response, with a beta coefficient of -0.56 and a P-value of 1.5 x 10^-26, highlighting its significance.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: For the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) antibody response, the SNP rs6914950 was found to correlate positively, with a beta coefficient of 0.35 and a P-value of 9.0 x 10^-13, marking it as an important factor.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: The SNP rs1471103672 was identified in relation to the FHA (pertussis filamentous hemagglutinin) response, showing a beta coefficient of -0.30 and a P-value of 9.8 x 10^-16, signaling a significant association with reduced antibody levels.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: This SNP, rs147857322, was associated with the PRN (pertactin) antibody response with a beta coefficient of 0.37 and a P-value of 4.2 x 10^-23, indicating a positive original finding.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: The variant rs545690952 was found to be associated with reduced DT antibody levels. It significantly downregulated HLA-DRB1 expression, evidenced by a P-value of 1.6 x 10^-4, illustrating its impact on vaccine response.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: The SNP rs72851029 showed an association with decreased PT antibody response, with a pooled P-value of 6.6 x 10^-25, demonstrating that its alternate thymine allele resulted in lower HLA-DRB1 expression.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: For the SNP rs2395471, a strong association was replicated concerning HLA-C expression, yielding a P-value of 1.14 x 10^-12, consistent with its previously known control of HIV-1.
title: High-resolution African HLA resource uncovers HLA-DRB1 expression effects underlying vaccine response

finding: This SNP was linked to OCD in the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) region and was just 6kb from the HLA-B gene, reflecting potential immune system implications in OCD.
title: Genome-wide association study identifies new loci associated with OCD

finding: The study indicated that the SNP rs699947, located in the promoter region of the VEGF gene, was associated with the mediation of hippocampal volume change following electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). This suggests that genetic variations at this locus could potentially influence neuroplastic responses in patients undergoing ECT, particularly in relation to remission of depressive symptoms.
title: Analyzing Fractal Dimension in Electroconvulsive Therapy: Unraveling Complexity in Structural and Functional Neuroimaging

finding: Variant rs766406 was linked to mean diffusivity of the inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus, establishing connections to sleep traits and their genetic underpinnings.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: The variant rs34556183 had genetic overlaps with mean diffusivity traits in the superior corona radiata, highlighting its role in sleep genetics.
title: Mapping sleep’s phenotypic and genetic links to the brain and heart: a systematic analysis of multimodal brain and cardiac images in the UK Biobank

finding: The rs2105898T variant was significantly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) in the Japanese population, replicating findings reported in European populations. However, this association was no longer significant when conditioned on <HLA-DRB1*15:01>, indicating that the association was secondary to the effects of this allele.
title: Genetic dissection of HLA-DRB1*15:01 and XL9 region variants in Japanese patients with systemic lupus erythematosus: Primary role for HLA-DRB1*15:01

finding: The rs9271593C variant also exhibited significant association with SLE in the Japanese population, consistent with previous reports from European populations. Similar to rs2105898, the association became non-significant when conditioned on <HLA-DRB1*15:01>.
title: Genetic dissection of HLA-DRB1*15:01 and XL9 region variants in Japanese patients with systemic lupus erythematosus: Primary role for HLA-DRB1*15:01

finding: The index variant rs9380529 at 6p21.31 was associated with Forced Vital Capacity (FVC) and in the 95% credible set, suggesting a negative effect on vital capacity which aligns with a higher IPF risk.
title: Leveraging global multi-ancestry meta-analysis in the study of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis genetics

finding: At the locus associated with FVC, the index variant rs28435135 showed a linkage disequilibrium with rs9380529 (r² = 0.28) indicating a relationship with lung function.
title: Leveraging global multi-ancestry meta-analysis in the study of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis genetics

finding: This variant was significantly associated with Type 1 diabetes (T1D) and rheumatoid arthritis with rheumatoid factor in both cohorts, UKBB and eMERGE. Its consistent association across studies suggested its relevance in both AD and immune-related disorders.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: This variant was significantly associated with intestinal malabsorption and ulcerative colitis. The associations underlined the overlapping pathophysiological mechanisms between gut disorders and Alzheimer’s disease.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: This variant showcased significant associations with intestinal malabsorption and ulcerative colitis in the discovery set, aligning with the bidirectional communication between gut microbiota and brain functions.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: Significantly associated with both intestinal malabsorption and ulcerative colitis, this variant further illustrated the connection between the immune response and Alzheimer’s disease pathology.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: Associations with intestinal malabsorption and ulcerative colitis were significant. This finding emphasized the potential overlap between gastrointestinal disorders and Alzheimer’s disease implications.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: This variant was associated with both ulcerative colitis and rheumatoid arthritis with rheumatoid factor, suggesting a connection between inflammatory conditions and Alzheimer’s disease risk.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: It was significantly associated with both intestinal malabsorption and disorders of metabolic metabolism, which supported the theory of Alzheimer’s being partly a metabolic disease.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: It demonstrated significant associations with rheumatoid arthritis with rheumatoid factor and replicated across both UKBB and eMERGE, showcasing its importance in Alzheimer’s disease and inflammation.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with multiple forms of arthritis, including rheumatoid arthritis, underlining its potential effects on inflammation related to Alzheimer’s disease.
title: Cross-phenotype associations between Alzheimer’s Disease and its comorbidities may provide clues to progression

finding: Variant rs1799971 in the OPRM1 gene was found to be significantly associated with PAU, with implications for addiction-related behaviors previously identified in opioid use disorder, emphasizing its importance in substance use genetics.
title: Multi-ancestry study of the genetics of problematic alcohol use in >1 million individuals

finding: The SNP rs456261 at 6p21.32 was found to be intronic to PFDN6, demonstrating a very strong association with CAP (p=4.00×10^{-28}), linking it to immune functions possibly via its role in protein folding.
title: A genome-wide association study of adults with community-acquired pneumonia

finding: The SNP rs2076775 was determined to be intronic to SYNGAP1 at 6p21.32, with a strong association with CAP (p=7.26×10^{-10}), implicating its role in neurodevelopmental aspects which may relate indirectly to immune responses.
title: A genome-wide association study of adults with community-acquired pneumonia

finding: The SNP rs213226 was identified as intergenic to RING1 and HCG25 on chromosome 6p21.32, with a significant p-value of 8.64×10^{-9}, contributing to the genetic architecture influencing CAP.
title: A genome-wide association study of adults with community-acquired pneumonia

finding: The SNP rs1799971, located in the OPRM1 gene, was identified as the lead SNP in the analysis with a p-value of 6.78 x 10^-10, demonstrating significant association with opioid use disorder (OUD). It was replicated as a known coding variant linked to opioid-related phenotypes, specifically in European American populations, with its heritability estimated at 11.3%.
title: Cross-ancestry meta-analysis of opioid use disorder uncovers novel loci with predominant effects on brain

finding: The SNP rs1235162 at the UBD-SNORD32B locus was established as a novel finding related to habitual coffee consumption in this research, which had not been previously reported.
title: Habitual Coffee Consumption Increases Risks for Metabolic Diseases: Genome-wide Association Studies and a Phenotype-wide Two Sample Mendelian Randomization Analysis

finding: The missense variant rs10305492 (A316T) in the <italic>GLP1R</italic> gene showed a significant RG-lowering effect and was second only to <italic>G6PC2</italic> variants in its impact.
title: Random glucose GWAS in 493,036 individuals provides insights into diabetes pathophysiology, complications and treatment stratification

finding: The common variant rs6923761 (G168S) showed a small RG-lowering effect alongside its role in blood glucose homeostasis.
title: Random glucose GWAS in 493,036 individuals provides insights into diabetes pathophysiology, complications and treatment stratification

finding: The rare variant rs146868158 (R421W) was linked to reduced responses to GLP-1R agonists, demonstrating its effect on GLP-1R functionality and RG.
title: Random glucose GWAS in 493,036 individuals provides insights into diabetes pathophysiology, complications and treatment stratification

finding: The variant rs1799971 was noted as a genome-wide significant (GWS) functional variant at OPRM1, with a p-value of 4.92×10⁻⁹ in the EUR GWAS. It is previously implicated as a risk factor for opioid addiction (OUD) and showed significance across multiple analysis types, reinforcing its status as a key risk locus.
title: Genome-wide association study and multi-trait analysis of opioid use disorder identifies novel associations in 639,709 individuals of European and African ancestry

finding: The SNP rs79704991 presented a p-value of 1.11×10⁻⁸ in the EUR meta-analysis, making it a significant association at the OPRM1 locus. It was found to have low linkage disequilibrium (LD) (r²=0.02) with rs1799971, marking it as another influential risk factor while analyzing OUD.
title: Genome-wide association study and multi-trait analysis of opioid use disorder identifies novel associations in 639,709 individuals of European and African ancestry

finding: In the cross-ancestry meta-analysis, rs9478500 emerged as a genome-wide significant variant, showing a p-value of 1.95×10⁻⁸. This intronic variant within OPRM1 was associated with OUD and had previously been documented as a GWS variant for opioid addiction in European cohorts.
title: Genome-wide association study and multi-trait analysis of opioid use disorder identifies novel associations in 639,709 individuals of European and African ancestry

finding: The SNP rs116113866 was associated with chronic HBV infection and initially suggested a null association with cervical cancer (OR = 1.04, 95% CI = 0.98-1.10, P-value = 0.209). However, after applying MR-PRESSO, it was causally associated with cervical cancer showing an odds ratio of 1.30 (95% CI = 1.12-1.51, P-value = 0.0263), although this finding was not statistically significant after Bonferroni corrections.
title: Hepatitis B infection is causally associated with extrahepatic cancers: a Mendelian randomization study

finding: The SNP was found to be associated with vorinostat response with a significant level (p=8.28 x 10^-7). It is a missense variant in the LTA gene, which influences immune responses and apoptosis, therefore potentially affecting the tumor's sensitivity to HDAC inhibitors like vorinostat.
title: Exome-wide association study reveals 7 functional variants associated with ex-vivo drug response in acute myeloid leukemia patients
